text: he was instantly recognizable and
utterly remarkable the visionary
scientist helpless in his hi-tech
wheelchair who nonetheless transformed
our view of the universe while a student
he developed the first signs of motor
neuron disease gradually his body shut
down till he could communicate only
using a computerized voice synthesizer
controlled to start with by hand it
didn't hold him back his fame sprang
from his book a brief history of time it
sold 10 million copies but though many
bought it rather fewer actually read it
his theories about time space and black
holes were stupendously difficult for
non specialists to grasp but he turned
out to have a genius for communication
he gave lectures and interviews and
became an unlikely celebrity I even
appeared in The Simpsons I don't like
your tone you are looking for trouble
you found it
yeah just try me you entered on episode
of Star Trek he played poker with Isaac
Newton his predecessor as Lucasian
Professor of mathematics at Cambridge
physics today that apple fell on my head
was the most momentous day in the
history of science
hardly Apple story again his private
life was complicated but his first wife
Jane he had three children and she
looked after him until in 1990 he left
her for his nurse Elaine they eventually
married only four claims to emerge that
Hawking had been physically abused
police investigated but the case was
dropped for lack of evidence
the couple later divorced he never lost
his sense of humor now by the end he
could only speak by twitching his cheek
to move an infrared beam
but it taught me not to pity myself and
to get on with what I still go to I am
happier now than before I developed the
condition if general relativity is
correct then universe is expanding yes
yes sir if you reverse time and the
universe is getting smaller all right in
2014 his life was dramatized in the
theory of everything with Eddie Redmayne
playing hookey to see what happened at
the beginning of time itself here you
are at Cambridge they unveiled a statue
of him a rare honor for someone still
living but few did more to transform our
understanding of the universe and to
overcome personal challenges
